Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Crossing numbers for topological drawings of the complete graph, rotation schemes, and interior triple systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Principal Investigator's research in Mathematics with a focus on the study of crossing numbers. Crossing numbers date back to World War II, when the mathematician Paul Tur√°n worked on a labor camp moving carts filled with bricks from kilns to storage places using a railway system. In his own words ''...the work itself was not difficult; the trouble was only at the crossings. The trucks generally jumped the rails there, and the bricks fell out of them; in short this caused a lot of trouble and loss of time which was rather precious to all of us..." He realized that the situation could be improved by a railway system with the smallest number of crossings. The general problem with an arbitrary number of kilns and storage places turned out to be extremely difficult and has not been solved to date. A generalized abstraction of this problem is to consider drawings where some points are to be connected by curves and the goal is to minimize the number of crossings. Crossing numbers are important to everyday life and technology. Drawings of graphs are a helpful tool to visually represent connections and interrelations among objects or subjects, such as maps, genealogy tress, or organizational charts. To ease the understanding of such information, drawings with few crossings are highly desirable. Crossing numbers are also important to the development of electronic circuits, such as computer processors, whose components must be connected by non crossing electrical links in order to avoid short circuits. The accessible nature of related problem statements and their important applications make this project suitable to the direct involvement of graduate and undergraduate students.

Minimizing the number of crossings in a drawing of a graph in the plane is a major problem in topological and geometric graph theory. Crossing numbers of the complete graph are particularly important because, using random embeddings, bounds on the crossing number of the complete graph imply bounds on the crossing number of arbitrary graphs. Separation of points by a straight line (halving lines, k-edges, k-sets) has extensively been used to understand the complexity of finite sets of points in the plane. The PI and coauthors recently developed a separation concept for topological drawings of the complete graph in the plane. They used this concept to settle a long standing crossing number conjecture for several families of drawings. The goal of this project is to use this separation concept as a new approach to the Harary-Hill conjecture on the topological crossing number of the complete graph and its variations to other topological settings. Being able to separate points in topological graph drawings opens up a world of possibilities; problems involving k-edges, halving lines, and convexity will be studied for the first time on this topological framework. The project will significantly advance the understanding of the fundamental structure of topological drawings of graphs in the plane.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the PI’s research in topological graph theory and combinatorial geometry, to tackle long-standing problems in crossing number theory. A graph is composed of vertices, typically represented by points, and edges, typically represented by curves joining the vertices. Only the pairs of vertices to be connected by edges is relevant, and so there are many ways to draw the same graph, and it can be drawn on different surfaces or spaces. In the theory of crossing numbers the goal is to find the minimum number of edge-crossings among all different drawings of a fixed graph on a given space. This minimum is called the crossing number of the graph in that space. Crossing numbers are important to the graph drawing community as one of the most significant aesthetic and readability criteria; and to the VLSI (very-large-scale-integration) community as a tool to minimize the VLSI layout area of a graph. 

 The crossing number of the complete graph (all pairs of vertices are joined by an edge) is of particular importance to the project because bounds on the crossing number of this graph provide bounds on any graph. The exact crossing number of the complete graph in the plane was conjectured by Harary and Hill in the 1950’s. After almost 60 years, with several partial results along the way, the conjecture was finally proved by the PI and collaborators for a large class of drawings. This was the first step of a series of results on the Harary-Hill conjecture, its variations to other spaces, and its extensions to multipartite graphs, where the vertices are partitioned into a certain number of classes and only edges between classes are allowed.

 Several of these results were part of the research funded by this grant including a full classification of all topological drawings of the complete graph on the plane with up to 9 vertices, providing experimentation tools for research in topological graph theory; settling a particular instance of the Blazek-Koman Conjecture, regarding drawings of graphs on books with a fixed number of pages, and general lower bound improvements; a characterization of the structure of centrally monotone drawings of complete graphs using rotation schemes, that is, this only depends on the order in which the edges leave the vertices; and expressing the number of crossings in a complete k-partite circle drawing as a function that only depends on how the k circles are separated by the triangles of the drawing.

This project highly contributed to the study of local crossing numbers as an alternative to crossing numbers, that is, minimizing the number of crossings per edge rather than the overall number of crossings. Among other things, the rectilinear (all edges are straight line segments) local crossing number of the complete graph was completely determined. This confirmed the occurrence of a contra intuitive behavior: drawings locally but not globally minimizing crossings. This behavior was observed for rectilinear drawings of complete bipartite graphs and some families of sparse graphs, for which general local crossing number bounds were provided. A key lemma, which seems to be a relevant tool for other separation and crossing number problems, states that any finite configuration of points in the plane determines a segment or two incident segments that separate the configuration with at least one third of the points on each side.

 Funded by this grant, the PI created the CSUN Crossing Numbers Research Group. The group has provided research opportunities to CSUN undergraduate and graduate students, many of them underrepresented and with no prior research experiences. It also provided mentoring opportunities for continuing participants who help new participants get started with the group activities. The group has become a gateway to other research opportunities for students. The majority of the group participants eventually turn to other professors in the department to work on an specific research project, apply to research programs offered by other institutions in the summer, or start graduate programs in Mathematics. The group has had a clear impact on the student research atmosphere within the Mathematics Department at CSUN as well as on the academic lives of its participants. 

 The grant directly funded 15 undergraduate students; 8 more graduate and 6 undergraduate students participated in the research group activities with no funding. From these students, 10 are women, 3 of which are currently working on their Master’s thesis under the PI’s supervision; 13 have graduated, 5 of which are currently in the CSUN’s Masters program and 4 others started Ph. D. programs at TU Berlin, University of California, Davis, Ohio State University, and University of Idaho, and 1 more is teaching full time at Las Positas College. Several of these students have presented their results at local, national, and even international conferences.
